header.type: HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS, SUBMISSIONS QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

testimony: Mr Chairperson, I would like to swear him in.  Please stand up.
Thank you.  Mr Chairperson, he has been properly sworn in.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Peter, you are here today to tell us the story about yourself.  Is that correct?
You are from Alexandria.  Is that correct?
Yes, that is correct, I am from Alexandria.
You said that what happened to you in 1986.

In 1986 while I was at home, I was sleeping in  my bed, but I was not under the blankets, I was just reading  a book, lying in the bed.  The police then came.  They were together with the Municipality Police.  They knocked at the door.  They did not knock in a proper way.
Was it at night or was it during the day?

It was before eight o' clock at night, they kicked the door.  At home when it was raining our door would not close properly.  They just pushed the door and it opened.  My sister was there.  They asked her for my brother.  She said that she did not know where my brother was.  They then asked where I was.  She answered by saying that she did not know where I was, because she just arrived  at home.  They wanted to search the house.  At that time while I was reading the book I fell asleep, but I could hear that there were people talking.  When I woke up it was the time when they were coming in my room.  The light was still on as I was reading the book.  They came to me and they asked where are others.  I said who are you talking about.  They then looked under the bed and they opened the wardrobe.
According to your knowledge, were there reasons for them, for searching for you, for looking for you?
Were you taking part in activities which will make the police to look for you?
When there was toy-toy in your area, in Alexandria, what would you do?
Were you toy-toying like the rest of the people?
Was there any youth organisation or a resident's organisation in which you were a member?
There was a youth organisation, but at that time I was not a member.
You said that they grabbed you by the chest.  What happened?
They took me out of the room.
Did they beat you all this time?
Yes, the two police which were here today, they were present.
Did they beat you when they grabbed you?
They beat me when they were taking me out of the room.  They beat me in the dining-room and then they took me outside.
They beat me with a sjambok.
They did not tell me why they were beating me, they just beat me.
They took you to the police station?
Yes, they took me to the police station.
What happened in the police station?  Can you please explain to us?

As I was in the police station I was bleeding, because they beat me in my one eye.  They took me with their police van to the charge office.  When we arrived there they let me sit down, they gave me a cloth so that I can stop the blood, they phoned the ambulance.  They phoned the ambulance, the doctor said that he will send me straight to hospital.  He said that he cannot do anything about the injury in my eye.
He sent me to Livingstone Hospital in Port Elizabeth.
Who was your doctor in Port Elizabeth?  Do you remember?
In Port Elizabeth, I do not remember.
But you stayed for how long?
I stayed for two weeks.  I was discharged in the third week.
Did you go to any attorney for advice about what happened to you?
The attorney visited me in the hospital, an indian attorney, Naidoo.
Did he say that he was from Port Elizabeth?
He just took a statement from me.
Did you see him, did you see Mr Naidoo after that?
No, I did not see him after that, but he gave my case to another attorney, Vanessa, in Port Elizabeth.
What did Vanessa do about this case?

I use to go to visit her in Port Elizabeth.  She will tell me to come back again and I would do that.  It was very difficult for me to go from Alexandria to Port Elizabeth, because I could not afford it financially.  She then told me that she was going to telephone, to phone me.
When you were released from the hospital were you arrested?
When I was discharged I stayed for a few days and I was arrested under the State of Emergency.
For how long were you detained?
They told us we were going to spend 180 days.
Do you still remember how many months did you stay?
If I am not mistaken, it is ten months.
In your statement you said you stayed for 11 months.
Yes, I think it is 11 months.
When you were detained under the State of Emergency what happened to you?
Were you tortured or were you beaten by the sjamboks or were you harassed?
No, I was not harassed, but my eye was very painful.
Were you beaten by a sjambok in your eye?
Do you have a request to make concerning this case?
Yes, I do have a request, because I do not think I will be able to go back to work.  I am still young and I would like the Commission to help me.

At home I am staying with my mother, my father passed away.  It is very difficult, because we are an extended family.  All of us are depending and are supporting, being supported by my mother.  I would like the Commission to help me.
Do you get a disability grant?
Yes, I do get a disability grant, but it expired.  I then reapplied for it.
For how long was it, did you not receive it?
What reasons were given to you?
They told me that I could, I am able to go back to work.
Do you have any other request to make or is that all you wanted to say before I hand over to the Chairperson?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Peter, you said  that you cannot work, you cannot go back to work because of the injuries you sustained in your eye.
Mr Chairperson, my eye is not functioning properly.  Nobody will hire me with such an eye.  Even this other side is not functioning properly.
Do I understand you well if I am saying that you need treatment for your eye?
Are you saying that one of your requests is that you want a specialist to look at your eye?
Yes, I would like that very much.
Thank you Mr Peter.  I will hand over to the Chairperson.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Peter, the story of the people in this country, those who were fighting for liberation will not end with names, such as your name, are being mentioned when this story is revealed to other generations.  The police will be implicated when this story is being told to the other generation.  The people such as the other professionals, such as doctors, refused to treat people.  You also mentioned such a doctor who refused to treat you because of the apartheid system.  These names will come and they will be revealed to people.  Sir, together with other Comrades, we do remember your struggle, your participation in the struggle.  We thank you very much.
